data.title: Inflation
data.solution:
N1 = int(input())
list1 = dict()
for i in range(N1):
    inputs = input().split()
    list1[inputs[0]] = float(inputs[1])
N2 = int(input())
list2 = dict()
for i in range(N2):
    inputs = input().split()
    list2[inputs[0]] = float(inputs[1])

N = 0
I = 0.0
for item in list1:
    if item in list2:
        I += (list2[item] - list1[item]) / list1[item]
        N += 1

print(f"{I/N*100:.2f}%")
data.statement: You have the nagging feeling that everything gets more expensive. Good that you kept your shopping receipts to verify that this is indeed the case! First calculate the <<percentage increase in price>> ([[price2]] - [[price1]]) / [[price1]] for each item that appears on both receipts, then <<average the percentage increases>> to estimate the inflation.

data.constraints:
0 < [[N1]],[[N2]] < 20
0.01 <= [[price1]], [[price2]]
No duplicate [[item]]s in the individual receipts.
There is always at least one [[item]] that appears on both receipts.
The average inflation is always positive.
data.stubGenerator:
read N1:int
loop N1 read item1:word(100) price1:float
read N2:int
loop N2 read item2:word(100) price2:float

write answer
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> An integer [[N1]] for the number of items of the old receipt.
<<Next [[N1]] lines:>> The name of the [[item]] and a floating point value [[price1]] separated by a space
<<Next Line:>> An integer [[N2]] for the number of items of the new receipt.
<<Next [[N2]] lines:>> The name of the [[item]] and a floating point value [[price2]] separated by a space
data.outputDescription: <<Line 1 :>> The inflation expressed as a percentage (the answer should end with {{%}}) rounded to the nearest 0.01% .

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

You have the nagging feeling that everything gets more expensive. Good that you kept your shopping receipts to verify that this is indeed the case! First calculate the percentage increase in price (price2 - price1) / price1 for each item that appears on both receipts, then average the percentage increases to estimate the inflation.
Input
Line 1: An integer N1 for the number of items of the old receipt.
Next N1 lines: The name of the item and a floating point value price1 separated by a space
Next Line: An integer N2 for the number of items of the new receipt.
Next N2 lines: The name of the item and a floating point value price2 separated by a space
Output
Line 1 : The inflation expressed as a percentage (the answer should end with %) rounded to the nearest 0.01% .
Constraints
0 < N1,N2 < 20
0.01 <= price1, price2
No duplicate items in the individual receipts.
There is always at least one item that appears on both receipts.
The average inflation is always positive.
Example
Input
1
Milk 1.55
1
Milk 1.65
Output
6.45%
